channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Throwing Stones and Slaughtering Sheep at the Hajj
item.media:description: Outside a slaughterhouse on the outskirts of Mecca, men hang around looking to work for tips, paid in cash or in chunks of meat.
item.description: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent making the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, picked up tips on how to practice some of the rites and rituals of the hajj.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Their Streets and Skies Suddenly Quiet, Syrians Watch Cease-Fire With Unease
item.media:description: A cafe in the government-held part of Aleppo on Tuesday.
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad’s supporters and opponents alike share misgivings. They know the truce was negotiated over their heads, and they do not know the details.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: The Push and Pull of Gender for Muslims at the Hajj
item.media:description: Women at the hajj, clockwise from left: on Ajyad Street, one of the main thoroughfares leading to the Grand Mosque in Mecca; Indonesian women rested on a sidewalk in the tent city of Mina, where nearly 2 million pilgrims slept for three days as part of their hajj rites; and the Times correspondent Diaa Hadid during the hajj.
item.description: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: ‘Lula,’ Brazil’s Ex-President, Is Charged With Corruption
item.media:description: The former Brazilian president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva during a news conference in March.
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.description: Prosecutors say that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva and his wife illegally benefited from about $1.1 million in work at a beachfront apartment paid for by a company seeking public contracts.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Justin Trudeau, Nearing a Year in Office, Tries to Recast Himself
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Parliament Hill in Ottawa in June.
item.description: Canada’s popular prime minister must soon demonstrate that he is not just a social media star but also a leader who will deliver on ambitious promises, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Wing Flap Confirmed as Malaysia Airlines Debris
item.media:description: Officials inspecting a piece of debris found off the coast of Tanzania this summer, more than two years after Malaysia Airlines’ Flight 370 disappeared. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau matched the piece’s serial number and confirmed that it is from the missing plane.
item.description: The Boeing 777-200 part, washed ashore on a Tanzanian island, came from Flight 370, which mysteriously disappeared in March 2014, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Mumbai Journal: Indians, Some Seeking Brighter Fortunes, Celebrate Vibrant Ganesh Festival
item.media:description: A procession with a giant idol of the elephant-headed god Ganesh headed toward the coast in Mumbai, India, on Thursday. The statue will be immersed in the ocean, marking the final day of the Ganesh festival.
item.description: A festival to worship the elephant-headed god began in 19th-century Mumbai as an anticolonial protest, but it has since spread across the country.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Ordered Philippine Killings, Professed Hit Man Testifies
item.media:description: Investigators examining the body of a victim thought to have been killed by a gunman for hire in the Philippine city of Caloocan, a part of greater Manila, in August.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: A spokesman denied the charges against President Duterte, who was accused in a Senate hearing of presiding over 1,000 killings as mayor of Davao City.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR and MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Russia’s Opposition, While Repressed, May Be Its Own Worst Enemy
item.media:description: Maria Baronova, a candidate for Parliament from the Open Russia movement, spoke on Thursday to a crowd in Moscow.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The chances are slim that opponents of President Vladimir V. Putin, divided and largely ineffective, will make gains in Sunday’s parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Syria Is Delaying Aid Deliveries in Violation of Cease-Fire, U.N. Says
item.media:description: Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, warned in Geneva on Thursday that the delivery of humanitarian aid that was part of the Syria cease-fire deal had not taken place.
item.description: A United Nations official said the Syrian government had not issued authorization for aid convoys to pass checkpoints.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Australia’s Leader Calls for National Gay Marriage Vote
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage at a rally in Sydney, Australia, in June.
item.description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull asked Parliament to pass a bill that would set up a nonbinding plebiscite asking Australians to vote yes or no on the issue.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: British Lawmakers Condemn 2011 Intervention in Libya
item.media:description: A rebel fighter prepared to tow away a government truck mounted with a machine gun that was hit by a NATO airstrike near Brega, Libya, in April 2011.
item.description: A parliamentary committee said the former prime minister, David Cameron, “was ultimately responsible for the failure to develop a coherent Libya strategy.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: The Surprising Science of Cease-Fires: Even Failures Can Help Peace
item.media:description: Children on a carousel in Douma, Syria, on Tuesday, the second day of Eid al-Adha. Cease-fires can create something like a virtuous cycle, but there is also a flip side: the vicious cycle.
item.description: Cease-fires can create something like a virtuous cycle, making future pauses more likely. But beware the flip side: the vicious cycle.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: E.U. Leaders, Struggling to Respond to Crises, Gather in Slovakia
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London in July against Britain’s decision to leave the European Union. Members of the bloc are divided over how to handle negotiations with London.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Representatives of 27 member nations — all but Britain, which voted in June to leave the bloc — remain divided over illegal migration, security and the economy.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: India Prevents Kashmiri Activist From Traveling to U.N. Meeting
item.media:description: Protesters in Srinagar, the capital of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, on Tuesday.
item.description: The activist, Khurram Parvez, was to submit a report to the United Nations Human Rights Council on the situation in the Indian-controlled portion of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Pauline Hanson, Australian Senator, Urges End to Muslim Immigration
item.description: Newly elected to the Senate, Ms. Hanson, the leader of the One Nation party, also called for a ban on the burqa.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Tycoon Behind Grindr Will Pay $1.14 Billion in Divorce
item.description: The transfer of shares to Zhou Yahui’s wife is the latest example of a split affecting the fortunes of a Chinese company.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG
item.category: Beijing Kunlun World Wide Technology Share Company

item.title: Train Crash in Pakistan Kills at Least 4
item.description: A freight train was sitting idle after it had run over a man on the tracks, a senior official was quoted as saying by the news media, when a commuter train smashed into its rear.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Japan’s Main Opposition Party Elects First Female Leader
item.description: Renho Murata, chosen as head of the Democratic Party, became the third woman to take up a prominent political job in Japan in less than two months.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Hinkley Point Nuclear Plant Will Go Ahead, Britain Says
item.description: The project, financed in part with French and Chinese investment, had been postponed in July, angering its international partners.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Nearly Two-Thirds of Refugee Children Attend No School, U.N. Says
item.media:description: Syrian children at a camp in Greece, near Idomeni, in August.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: A new report by the United Nations pointed to the crisis in refugee education before a summit on refugees at the annual General Assembly next week.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Top Investigator in Case of Missing Students in Mexico Resigns
item.media:description: Images of the 43 undergraduates missing from a teachers college in Ayotzinapa at a protest camp, set up in front of the attorney general’s office, in August, in Mexico City.
item.description: Tomás Zerón de Lucio left his post as head of the Criminal Investigation Agency amid an internal affairs inquiry into his office’s handling of the case.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Obama Prods Netanyahu After Signing of U.S.-Israel Aid Deal
item.description: Mr. Obama stressed the importance of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, an imperative he said was as vital to Israel’s security as the military aid itself.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Myanmar’s Leader Has a Longtime Champion in Mitch McConnell
item.description: Visiting Washington this week, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will reunite with the Senate majority leader, who has supported her attempts to promote democracy at home for years.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: ‘All Syrians Are Tired of This Absurd War’: Voices From the Cease-Fire
item.media:description: An Eid festival in Dummar, a suburb of Damascus, on Wednesday.
item.description: The truce held without many notable violations in its first two days. How did it change the daily lives of people around the country?
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Prostate Cancer Study Details Value of Treatments
item.media:description: Robert Boulton, a prostate cancer patient, was initially assigned to receive active monitoring but switched to radiation treatment after four years, when his P.S.A. went up.
item.media:credit: Alexander Atack for The New York Times
item.description: A 10-year study of more than 1,500 men with early prostate cancer found no difference in death rates between men who had surgery or radiation and those who monitored the disease.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY

item.title: U.N. Chief Says North Korea Has Spawned Unprecedented Tension
item.media:description: A celebration rally on Tuesday, in Kim Il-sung Square in Pyongyang, North Korea, following the country’s test of a nuclear warhead last week.
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged the Security Council to take “urgent actions” in a news conference before his last annual General Assembly session as the United Nations leader.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Muslim Teenager Proposes Emoji of Woman Wearing a Head Scarf
item.media:description: Potential emojis depicting headwear worn by Muslims.
item.description: A 15-year-old high school student in Berlin is proposing an emoji with a head scarf, or hijab, to represent the millions of Muslim women who wear one.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Scottish Nurse Who Had Ebola Is Cleared of Misconduct
item.media:description: Pauline Cafferkey, second from left, in Edinburgh on Wednesday. She contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and was accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials.
item.description: The nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and had been accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: After Years of War, Celebrities Find a Syrian Group to Back
item.media:description: Syrian Civil Defense volunteers, known as White Helmets, carried a survivor who was pulled from the debris of an airstrike in Aleppo on July 25.
item.description: Some in Hollywood are lobbying for the White Helmets to receive the Nobel Peace Prize.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: Obama Pledges to Lift All Sanctions Against Myanmar
item.media:description: Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi arrived at the White House on Wednesday.
item.description: President Obama, who met on Wednesday with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s leader, sought to reward the country for its efforts to establish a more democratic government.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Memo From Britain: Theresa May, Britain’s Prime Minister, Plays the ‘Brexit’ Waiting Game
item.media:description: Despite pressure from Brussels to move quickly, Prime Minister Theresa May has said that Britain will not formally begin the two-year negotiation process to leave the European Union until the first quarter of 2017.
item.description: David Cameron’s successor has said little about how her country will withdraw from the European Union, and tough decisions loom.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Winners and Losers as Europe Tries to Erase Borders for TV and Films
item.media:description: The BBC’s headquarters in London. Under new rules, so-called video-on-demand services from national broadcasters, like the BBC iPlayer, may become more readily available across the European Union.
item.description: The proposal aims to allow people across the bloc to stream shows online and give national broadcasters a Continent-size audience.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Opposition Figure’s Rise Could Pave Way for Female Leaders in Japan
item.media:description: Renho Murata, center, at a debate in Tokyo with her political opponents Yuichiro Tamaki, left, and Seiji Maehara. Ms. Murata is vying to become the first woman to lead the Democratic Party.
item.description: The election of Renho Murata as head of the Democratic Party would be a step toward gender equality in a country that has lagged in promoting women.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: An Unlikely Crime in One-Party China: Election Fraud
item.media:description: Delegates to the National People’s Congress in Beijing in March. The nearly 3,000 members of the congress, which each March meets as a full body for less than two weeks, ratify laws and government programs.
item.description: Forty-five lawmakers, all from Liaoning Province, have been expelled from the National People’s Congress in a vote-buying scandal, the state news media said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Refugees Pour Out of Turkey Once More as Deal With Europe Falters
item.media:description: A camp for migrants and asylum seekers on the Greek island of Chios this month. More than 1,000 refugees arrived in Greece last week, nearly double the number the previous week.
item.description: The number of refugees arriving in Greece nearly doubled last week, to more than 1,000. Many are realizing that an agreement to stanch the flow is not being enforced.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: After North Korea Flooding, Relief Agencies Help Tens of Thousands
item.media:description: The damage caused by heavy flooding of the Tumen River in North Hamgyong Province, North Korea.
item.media:credit: Murat Sahin/Unicef, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: North Korea reported hundreds of people dead or missing but has not publicly appealed for outside help, instead relying on internal mobilization.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Jutta Limbach, First Woman to Lead Germany’s Highest Court, Dies at 82
item.media:description: Jutta Limbach in 2002 at a session of the Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany.
item.description: Ms. Limbach, who was 11 when World War II ended, also led a commission to mediate disputes about the restitution of art seized by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: What in the World: What’s Hebrew for ‘When in the Course of Human Events’?
item.media:description: The Declaration of Independence begins with Thomas Jefferson’s famous phrase “when in the course of human events” — and so did an early draft of Israel’s founding document.
item.description: Early drafts of Israel’s founding document borrowed heavily from Thomas Jefferson in the Declaration of Independence, among other famous writings.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: What in the World: Immortalized on the Streets of St. Petersburg: Kim Jong-il and Mannerheim
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Andrey Kuzmin/shutterstock
item.description: To the bafflement and irritation of many people in St. Petersburg, Russia, their city has recently honored three people they would hardly call heroic or beloved.
item.dc:creator: LINCOLN PIGMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Venezuela: The Opposition Mobilizes for the Presidential Referendum
item.media:description: Venezuelans marching this month in Caracas in protest against the government.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The country needs to hammer out a democratic transition, but success is unlikely if mass demonstrations are halted.
item.dc:creator: FRANCISCO SUNIAGA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Where Is Europe’s Moral Authority?
item.media:description: A Macedonian soldier placing barbed wire on a new fence along the border with Greece near Gevgelija, Macedonia.
item.description: When Angela Merkel stands up to the populists who fought the Greek bailout and want to keep out refugees, she’s keeping the flame of principle alive.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Guatemala’s Fragile Progress
item.media:description: Protesting in June in Guatemala City against corruption involving the former president Otto Pérez Molina.
item.description: Victories against pervasive organized crime could be undone without continued U.S. and United Nations support.
item.dc:creator: ANITA ISAACS
item.category: International Commission Against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
